On this page

26. Testing Infrastructure ​

Vex provides a first-class testing experience inspired by modern systems languages like Go, but tailored for Vex's contract capabilities and type system. The testing infrastructure consists of the vex test CLI command and the testing standard library.

26.1 vex test CLI ​

The vex test command automates the process of discovering, compiling, and running tests.

Usage ​

bash
$ vex test [flags] [pattern]

Examples ​

bash
$ vex test ./...                    # Run all tests in current module and submodules (Recursive)
$ vex test src/calc                 # Run tests in specific directory
$ vex test -v                       # Verbose: Show logs (t.log) even for passing tests
$ vex test -run TestAdd             # Run only tests matching regex "TestAdd"
$ vex test -short                   # Skip long-running tests
$ vex test -bench .                 # Run benchmarks

Discovery Rules ​

The vex test command looks for files ending in _test.vx or .test.vx.

  • Naming Pattern: *_test.vx (Recommended)
  • Location: Test files should stay alongside source files (e.g., calc.vx and calc_test.vx).
  • Entrypoint: The CLI automatically generates a main_test.vx harness that imports your test files and executes them via testing.Runner.

26.2 testing Library ​

The standard library provides the primitives for writing tests and benchmarks.

Core Structures ​

T (Test Context) ​

The T struct is passed to every test function. It handles failure reporting, logging, and skipping.

rust
fn TestExample(t: &T!) {
    if 2 + 2 != 4 {
        t.err("Math is broken");
    }
}

Methods:

  • t.err(msg: string): Marks test as failed but continues execution.
  • t.fatal(msg: string): Marks test as failed and stops execution of the current test immediately (panic).
  • t.skip(msg: string): Skips the current test.
  • t.log(msg: string): Log generic info (visible only with -v or on failure).
  • t.cleanup(fn(): void): Registers a callback to run after the test flows.

Assert (Assertions) ​

Helper struct for succinct checks.

rust
import { Assert } from "testing";

fn TestWithAssert(t: &T!) {
    let assert = Assert.new(t);
    
    assert.equal_i64(10, 10, "Should be equal");
    assert.is_true(true, "Should be true");
}

26.3 Writing Tests ​

Tests are ordinary functions exported from a test file, starting with the Test prefix and accepting &T! parameter.

rust
// math_test.vx
import { add } from "./math.vx";
import { T } from "testing";

export fn TestAdd(t: &T!) {
    let result = add(2, 3);
    if result != 5 {
        t.err(f"Expected 5, got {result}");
    }
}

Table Driven Tests ​

Vex supports table-driven tests naturally using structs and loops.

rust
export fn TestAddTable(t: &T!) {
    struct Case { a: i32, b: i32, expected: i32 }
    
    let cases = [
        Case { a: 1, b: 2, expected: 3 },
        Case { a: 0, b: 0, expected: 0 },
        Case { a: -1, b: 1, expected: 0 },
    ];
    
    for c in cases {
        t.run(f"Adding {c.a}+{c.b}", |sub_t| {
            if add(c.a, c.b) != c.expected {
                sub_t.err("Failed");
            }
        });
    }
}

26.4 Benchmarking ​

Benchmarks are functions starting with Benchmark and accepting &B!.

rust
import { B } from "testing";

export fn BenchmarkAdd(b: &B!) {
    // b.n is provided by the runner
    for i in 0..b.n {
        add(2, 3);
    }
}

Running Benchmarks:

bash
$ vex test -bench .

The runner automatically adjusts b.n until the function runs for a statistically significant duration (default 1s).

26.5 Internal Architecture ​

When vex test runs:

  1. Scanner: Scans directories for export fn Test*(t: &T!) signatures.
  2. Codegen: Generates a temporary vex_test_runner.vx file.
    rust
    // Generated
import { Runner, TestCase } from "testing";
import { TestAdd } from "./math_test.vx";

fn main() {
    let runner = Runner.new();
    runner.add(TestCase { name: "TestAdd", test_fn: TestAdd });
    runner.run();
}
  3. Compilation: Uses vex compile to build this runner.
  4. Execution: Runs the resulting binary.
